item.title: Reeves Hails Fiscal Rules in Surprise Appearance Beside Starmer
item.description: Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves made an unscheduled appearance alongside Keir Starmer the day after she was reduced to tears in Parliament, as the UK’s Labour government battles to end any doubts over her future in the role.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Milligan, Lucy White, Freya Jones

item.title: US House Nears Passage of Trump’s Tax Bill After All-Nighter
item.description: The US House of Representatives is on track to pass Donald Trump’s tax and spending bill Thursday, allowing lawmakers to meet the president’s self-imposed July 4 deadline after negotiating all night long.
item.dc:creator: Erik Wasson, Steven T. Dennis, Ken Tran, Jack Fitzpatrick

media:content.media:description: House Speaker Mike Johnson in the Capitol on Wednesday

item.title: Merz Signals Germany Won’t Compromise on Bank Deposit Protection
item.description: Chancellor Friedrich Merz signaled he won’t give up Germany’s opposition to joint European Union deposit insurance, a scheme large banks view as key to forging closer financial ties in the bloc.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Comfort, Michael Nienaber

media:content.media:description: German Chancellor Friedrich Merz on July 3. Photographer: Sean Gallup/Getty Images

item.title: Savannah Bet Its Economy on a Big Hyundai Plant. Now It Has to Find the Workers
item.description: The historic city, known for gardens and gothic mystery, is leaving no stone unturned as it helps the South Korean auto giant staff up a futuristic new factory
item.dc:creator: Michael Sasso

item.title: It’s a Brutal Anniversary for Britain’s Starmer
item.description: As he prepares to mark his first year in power, the prime minister is finding defeat around every turn.
item.dc:creator: Alan Crawford

item.title: Trump’s Vietnam Deal Shows China Tariffs Won’t Fall Much Further
item.description: President Donald Trump’s new trade deal with Vietnam sends a clear signal about where US tariffs on Chinese goods might ultimately land, as talks between Washington and Beijing continue following their recent truce.

item.title: Lutnick Nears Crunch Time to Deliver on His Trade-Deal Swagger
item.description: With President Donald Trump’s budget megabill all but wrapped up and the Iran crisis subsiding, trade wars are back center-stage in Washington — putting Commerce Secretary Howard Lutnick where he’s happiest: in the thick of the action.

item.title: UK Firms Plan to Boost Hiring in Sign of Rebounding Jobs Market
item.description: UK firms plan to ramp up hiring at the fastest pace since before Labour announced higher payroll taxes and a minimum wage hike, a sign of the jobs market bouncing back after a sharp fall in employment.
item.dc:creator: Tom Rees, Irina Anghel

item.title: Four Things to Watch in Thai Political Crisis After Prime Minister Suspended
item.description: Thai Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra faces an uncertain future and could become the third leader from the Shinawatra clan member to lose power over the past 19 years.

item.title: Indonesia Says $34 Billion in Trade, Investment MOU With US in Pipeline
item.description: The US and Indonesia will sign trade and investment pacts worth $34 billion as part of efforts to secure a deal on tariffs ahead of a July 9 deadline.
item.dc:creator: Grace Sihombing

media:content.media:description: Workers produce sports apparel at a factory in Central Java, Indonesia.

item.title: Japan’s 2025 Wage Talks Conclude With Highest Gain in 34 Years
item.description: Japan’s annual wage negotiations concluded with the largest pay increase in 34 years, an outcome that supports the central bank’s view that a cycle of higher wages and prices is emerging.
item.dc:creator: Erica Yokoyama

item.title: China Vows Retaliation If It’s Hurt by US-Vietnam Trade Deal
item.description: China said it was examining a trade deal that the US and Vietnam clinched and would retaliate if its interests were hurt — a sign that tensions between Beijing and Washington risk worsening as more of the pacts are finalized.
item.dc:creator: James Mayger, Yujing Liu

item.title: Top Chinese Official Softens Tone on US, Says War ‘Unimaginable’
item.description: A senior Chinese official said he was “optimistic” about the future of his nation’s ties with the US, among the most upbeat comments given by Beijing in recent weeks about a relationship upended by Donald Trump’s tariffs.

item.description: Thailand’s suspended Prime Minister Paetongtarn Shinawatra was sworn in as a cabinet minister Thursday, a maneuver allowing her to attend ministerial meetings while awaiting the results of a court review of her alleged misconduct.

item.description: South Korean President Lee Jae Myung said it remains unclear if trade talks between Seoul and Washington can result in a deal before next week’s deadline to avert sweeping tariffs from President Donald Trump.

item.title: German Coalition Resists Calls for Wider Electricity-Tax Cut
item.description: German Chancellor Friedrich Merz’s ruling coalition rebuffed calls to expand an electricity-tax discount to include households and additional companies, saying they’ll only do so when they have “financial leeway.”

item.description: President Donald Trump said he had reached a trade deal with Vietnam following weeks of intense diplomacy between the nations and ahead of a deadline next week that would have seen higher tariffs imposed on the country’s imports.

item.description: The trade truce between Washington and Beijing may be holding for now, but China is increasingly wary about what’s happening elsewhere: US efforts to forge deals that could isolate Chinese firms from global supply chains.

item.title: Singapore’s Wong Urges Restraint in Thai-Cambodia Border Dispute

item.title: US-Vietnam Deal Risks China Reprisal, Bloomberg Economics Says
item.description: A new trade deal between the US and Vietnam risks provoking retaliatory steps from China as the accord includes a 40% tariff on goods deemed to be transshipped through the Southeast Asian country, according to Bloomberg Economics.
item.dc:creator: Swati Pandey

item.title: Iran Strikes Set Back Nuke Program by Up to Two Years, US Says
item.description: US airstrikes on Iran set back the country’s nuclear program by one to two years, a Pentagon spokesman said, adding to uncertainty around the status of the country’s facilities after President Donald Trump said they’d been obliterated.

item.description: As President Donald Trump and his advisers begin weighing replacements for Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell, they’re running into one significant complication: It’s not clear that Powell will leave the US central bank next year.

item.description: Gamblers are raising the alarm about a $1.1 billion tax hike buried in the Senate GOP’s tax bill that would slash their net winnings and potentially charge income tax when they break even or lose money.

item.title: Fed Chair Should Be Investigated by Congress, FHFA Head Says
item.description: Bill Pulte, who leads the Federal Housing Finance Agency, called on Congress to investigate Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell, alleging that his recent testimony to the Senate about the central bank’s planned renovations to its headquarters was “deceptive.”
item.dc:creator: Paige Smith

media:content.media:description: Jerome Powell, chairman of the US Federal Reserve, arrives for a Senate Banking, Housing, and Urban Affairs Committee hearing in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, June 25, 2025. Powell said a proposal to eliminate the interest paid to banks that deposit cash at the central bank would not save money, and moving back to a scarce reserves regime would be challenging and risk volatility.

item.title: Pentagon Faces Questions Over Move to Halt Weapons for Ukraine
item.description: The Pentagon came under criticism Wednesday for its decision to halt sending air defense missiles to Ukraine, with lawmakers on both sides of the aisle arguing that move was shortsighted at a time when Russia has ramped up its missile and drone barrages.
item.dc:creator: Courtney McBride, Jamie Tarabay

media:content.media:description: Rescue services search the site of a Russian air strike on a residential building in Kyiv, Ukraine, on Monday, June 23, 2025. Russia unleashed its latest missile and drone strike on Kyiv, killing at least seven people, as Moscow steps up its aerial attacks on civilian infrastructure. Photographer: Andrew Kravchenko/Bloomberg
